newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Two Swedes expelled from Russia for spying - agency.
newsitem.headline: Two Swedes expelled from Russia for spying - agency.

text.p: Two Swedes, one of them a senior diplomat, have been expelled from Russia for alleged spying, the Swedish news agency TT reported on Wednesday.
Swedish authorities refused early comment on the affair.
TT quoted Russian media as saying the man was alleged to have been spying in St. Petersburg, Russia's second city. A Swedish diplomat had also been expelled, the agency added.
TT reported that the Swedish man had been arrested in February and had confessed to spying. He and the diplomat had already left Russia, the agency added.

The Russian Interfax news agency quoted Boris Kostenko, head of the information department of the Federal Security Service, as saying a Swedish military intelligence agent had been unmasked in February.

"He confirmed that last winter Hans Peter Nordstrem, a go-between for the Swedish military intelligence, and a Russian citizen who had been engaged by the intelligence earlier had been detained," Interfax said from Moscow.
Kostenko said diplomatic channels had been used after the investigation to make Sweden "withdraw the senior diplomat from Russia".
Kostenko refused to name the Russian agent or the Swedish diplomat or give the exact date when the latter had left Russia.
The Russian Nezavisimaya Gazeta daily newspaper said Nordstrem, a businessman born in 1964, had entered Russia on February 21 1996.
"According to certain sources his company had been set up by the Swedish military intelligence for covert operations in Russia," Nezavisimaya said.
